properties.media:imagetext:
is still too high for this small boat to get up the Gorges.
expect to
start any day.
Just now at Chungking we are borrowing gas from the
Commission five thousand gallons at the time and having to argue and
beg for it each
Regarding spare
parts this is going to be less complicated for a while
because we do
not have to worry about the Commodores and the Dolphis and the
Stinsons.
They are only doing about one third of the flying they were doing and
if the Japanese
take Ichang the Commodores will probably entirely so all we
consider are
the DCtwosâ€¢
Unfortunately owing to the uncertainty
difficulty we were having in getting US dollars and the delay and the
large amount already in Hongkong for which CNAC owed PASCO, I cancelled all orders
already sent in and
sending in any more. However now that we have cleared up
everything in Hong Kong I think it is safe to order what we need so we
working on some orders that will cover our needs in this respect.
Regarding the adjustment of routes this is going to be a tough problem.
CNAC is flying Chungking Ichang three times per week and getting full loads out of
Ichang of evacuees but this will end soon and apparently the Japanese are pushing
Ichang with
little resistance.
That leaves us with
Chungkingxxxd
Chengtu,
and Chungking Kurming both of which are booming and I think will bring us
nearly
two hundred and fifty thousand dollars per month alone. We are also
trying
to get into Hanoi from Chungking which I think will stand two xank trips
per week with
probably seventy percent capacity. All of this will keep CNAC
in business very confortably and allow a small profit if we can continue to buy
US dollars at the
rate for our needs. We are also flying once a week to
Hongkong at night loaded to capacity but when we get into Hanoi we plan to out
that out.
Eurasia is flying Hanoi Kunming twice a week with low percentage because
of the railway service
competing. They also fly Kunming Chengtu and get very little
now that we are flying Chungking Kunming. They are also
flying Chengtu Sian and
Sian Lanchow ank but not getting much revenue. In September and October, after they lost
their Hongkong Hankow service I understand their losses were terrific and they are
all scared. They forget the big losses CNAC had when the wer started and we loss all our
lines and had to develop others and how we were not allowed to share the Hankow
Hongkong line with Eurasia.
Actually Eurasias lines are nearly as good as ours and
I am certain Eurasia could develop a profitable business with what they have if they
handled it properly but Eurasia as you know has its own systen of dissipating its
profits
and
its reserve sol
that although it has had more revenue all this year
than CNAC and should have a big reserve it is just about on the rocks and the
Ministry is faced with the
prospects of subsidizing them and the Ministry hasnt
the money. To try to talk justice or contract or logic to the Minister or the
Ministry
would be
like- well the most useless thing you can think of, so I guess
there will be some sort of compromise but just now I am protesting like the .
deuce and threatening all
sorts of things. I hope in the end to obtain, 1) not too
great competition from Eurasia in schedules and the ability to reduce that through
superior operations and equipment, 2) the five year extension of our contract , IN
WRITING, 3) the the recognition as being permanent
our newly developed lines
Chungking Hongkong and Chungking Kunming, 4) the Eurasia competition to cease when
the war is over.
That is my idea of wishful thinking.
Anyway to get back to my original idea, if I can get these items settled
